risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Companion Animal Euthanasia Training Academy, Lutz, FL, USA

sect2.title: 10.1 Introduction
sect2.para: Supporting a devoted caregiver with the euthanasia of their pet is a regular part of the animal end‐of‐life (EOL) or hospice experience. Animal hospice revolves around the idea that death may come in either form: naturally, when a dying body shuts down on its own, or through the medical act of euthanasia. Euthanasia comes from the Greek words “eu” [good] and “thanatos” [death], and when performed properly, it is a smooth, peaceful passingch0022-c10-bib-0001. The goal of human hospice care is to neither hasten nor postpone death. When working with animals and the inherent differences between human and veterinary medicine, there is often greater permission to quicken death when suffering is present or pending. Euthanasia is generally accepted when an animal’s welfare is at risk, including when the caregiver burden has become too great, and they are struggling to provide adequate palliative care to their pet.

Euthanasia is conducted for a variety of reasons across many animal industries, including lab animal research, zoo and wildlife care, hobby farming, animal shelters, and private companion animal practice. Euthanasia tends to refer to a more singular act based on an animal’s physical or behavioral need rather than a large volume of herd animals requiring slaughter and depopulation. Slaughter and depopulation killing methods are very different from those used in companion animal hospicech0022-c10-bib-0002. Euthanasia is accepted by many cultures and religions around the world, although the choice to proceed remains highly personal and is often based on the relationship between humans and animals ch0022-c10-bib-0003.

As the International Association for Animal Hospice and Palliative Care (IAAHPC) explains, opting for euthanasia during the course of hospice care may be necessary and should not be viewed as a failurech0022-c10-bib-0004. In this situation, a caregiver’s intention may be the natural death of their pet, but the circumstances of their pet’s health, both physical and mental, require euthanasia. These physical and mental ailments include severe pain, breathing difficulty, uncontrollable seizures, and fear. Allowing a pet to die when their body picks the time is very attractive to caregivers who would rather not make the decision to end life. In a brief survey of caregivers working with this author, 95% of caregivers given the choice of how they want their pet to die said they prefer a natural death but were open to euthanasia if the veterinarian thought it best. The remaining 5% were split between wanting a hospice‐supported natural death and wanting a planned euthanasia with no desire for natural death. The goal of animal hospice places more emphasis on the time leading up to death to ensure it is comfortable and safe, and to allow death to come in any form. In other words, hospice is more about the journey than the destination.

Providing a compassionate euthanasia experience must consider the actions of the veterinary team before, during, and after death. Beforehand, veterinarians and veterinary technicians will be part of the discussion to determine if euthanasia is warranted and to address caregiver perspectives, beliefs, and feelings. These are often complex conversations demanding patience, compassion, and strong communication skills. During euthanasia, veterinarians and technicians work together to ensure the medical procedure itself is problem‐free. After euthanasia, the actions of the staff and how they care for the deceased pet are often just as meaningful to the caregiver. Endings matter, and it’s important for technicians to recognize that the euthanasia experience is more than just the act of giving euthanasia solution during the appointment. It is a collective experience that may span days to weeks.

sect2.title: 10.2 Defining Euthanasia and Dysthanasia
sect2.para: Having a term like euthanasia, which means a good death, gives us something to strive for. It’s a declaration that we want a good death and not a bad one. What actually defines a good death requires a bit more exploration. One person may view the experience very differently than another. Euthanasia in companion animals has been well studied, and some definitions have emerged to guide technicians and veterinary teams in achieving it [ch0022-c10-bib-0005, ch0022-c10-bib-0006] and avoiding dysthanasia (the opposite of euthanasia, also from the Greek language) ch0022-c10-bib-0007.

When caregivers are asked what’s important to them during euthanasia, there are five things that rise to the top (seeTable 10.1). Caregivers who have these conditions met rank their euthanasia experiences the highest when compared to caregivers who do not. They have confidence in the manner in which their pet died, with more control over the circumstances. Veterinary technicians help to increase caregiver comfort with the euthanasia details that matter most to them. Often just asking what’s important to caregivers is enough to set the stage for a more meaningful death.

Assisting with euthanasia appointment planning will be a large part of a technician’s role. The nature of animal hospice as a journey provides time for such conversations to occur. Veterinarians will usually be the ones to broach the subject of euthanasia; however, a technician can ask how a caregiver feels about the option. How a caregiver feels about euthanasia is considered a psychosocial factor (Communication Corner 10.1).

Euthanasia in an emergency situation tends to be the most difficult for caregivers. Emergencies by nature are surprising and unexpected, with little to no time to preplan for special touches during euthanasia (e.g. having loved ones present or adequate time to say goodbye). Emergencies can feel very clinical and uncaring even when veterinary teams try their best to create a calm, gentle setting. It’s possible that the veterinarian may decide to forego sedation during euthanasia if the pet’s condition is critical (e.g. struggling to breathe). If an emergency euthanasia has to be conducted, proceeding at home may be the best option to fulfill some important wishes of caregivers.

What has the death of previous pets looked like?
What is your goal for this pet’s EOL journey?
How would you feel if your pet died naturally without euthanasia?
What is important to you during your pet’s euthanasia?
What concerns, if any, do you have related to euthanasia?

sect2.para: Home tends to be quieter than hospitals and as a general rule, loved ones are more present, including other family petsch0022-c10-bib-0008. Animal hospice euthanasia is often conducted in the home, including during emergencies of all kinds. There are a few key differences from in‐clinic euthanasia, the first being the absence of backup supplies and available personnel. Animal hospice providers will need to bring all necessary items to the home, plus extras in case complications arise. Chapter 11 will describe home euthanasia preparedness in more detail.

Companion animal euthanasia is defined as the proper use of techniques to end the life of an animal with minimal to no pain or anxiety, best facilitated through the use of sedatives/anesthetics, that allows the informed pet owner to remain present for the entirety of the procedurech0022-c10-bib-0009. The definition has evolved over the years to include more of the caregiver’s perspective and not just the medical act itself, although this remains at the heart of the definition. It starts by considering what is best for the patient’s welfare during euthanasia, focusing on the need to avoid pain and stress, and even fear in the final moments of life. Caregivers want their pets to be peaceful during every part of the process, especially when euthanasia is part of the hospice journey and the human–animal bond (HAB) is strong. The definition also includes the use of sedatives/anesthetics that will cause the pet to be either deeply relaxed or sleeping. This pre‐euthanasia sleep has gained popularity in recent years and is now advocated for by groups such as the American Veterinary Medical Association (AVMA), American Animal Hospital Association (AAHA), the Fear Free Program, and the Companion Animal Euthanasia Training Academy (CAETA).

The absence or presence of dysthanasia, the opposite of euthanasia, is determined by those who are present during the appointment. Dysthanasia is a highly subjective impression of how well things went for the patient. Medically speaking, dysthanasia only occurs if the patient has a difficult death, with obvious pain and distress. Caregivers will find this very upsetting and be understandably unhappy or even angry with the veterinary staff. Beyond the medical procedure, dysthanasia may include the refusal of caregiver involvement, especially when they wanted to be present. They may rationalize that their pet’s death was more difficult without them present to offer love and comfort. Caregivers may feel their pet was alone and afraid. Dysthanasia is preventable by focusing on what leads to the safest and most comfortable experience for both the patient and the owner.

sect2.title: 10.3 Meaningful Components of the Euthanasia Appointment
sect2.para: Euthanasia is a unique blend of medicine and human grief and is sometimes hard to navigate for technicians. It can be considerably more complicated than other medical procedures due to the emotional needs of the caregivers and the toll it can take on veterinary personnel. The use of euthanasia guidelines founded on industry standards, yet personalized to the veterinary practice and team, will increase the likelihood of successful euthanasia appointments.

CAETA developed a list of components for inclusion in every euthanasia appointment (seeTable 10.2). Each appointment will be individualized to the needs of the caregiver and patient, but every experience will have the same standards in place for added consistency.

sect2.title: 10.3.1 Grief Support Materials Provided
sect2.para: Grief support materials will be provided to every family, regardless of the level of bond they appear to have with their pet. Materials may be in the form of digital web pages or downloadable info sheets; however, something tangible to offer is ideal. A small book, booklet, or brochure on grief and loss given by the technician sends a significant message of caring and support that will last beyond the appointment itself (seeFigure 10.2). Grief support materials can be shared within the family and become a personalized tribute to the pet that died.

sect2.title: 10.3.2 Outline Caregiver and Pet Preferences
sect2.para: Technicians will take time to outline/discuss what is important to caregivers and their pets. Such things can be discussed over the phone well in advance of the appointment. Preferences may also be shared through online intake forms and relayed to the veterinary staff. The goal is to give caregivers the opportunity to understand what is possible during euthanasia (e.g. loved ones present, music playing) and give them time to prepare before the day comes (Communication Corner 10.2). The nature of emergency euthanasia will limit preplanning options, but technicians can still make an effort to create a gentle, meaningful environment. Whether euthanasia is preplanned or performed the same day as the decision is made, patients can be handled with low‐stress/Fear Free® techniques and with their preferences considered (e.g. home environment, favorite foods).

listitem.para: Where do you want to gather? (e.g. home, hospital, park)
When would you like the appointment? (e.g. day, evening, weekend)
Who do you want to be there? (e.g. family, friends, other pets)
What will make your pet most comfortable? (e.g. sedatives, personal items, favorite treats)
What special touches would you like? (e.g. readings, music)
How would you like to handle aftercare arrangements? (e.g. contact the crematory themselves, assistance with burial)

sect2.title: 10.3.3 Offer Privacy Before and After Death
sect2.para: Privacy before and after death is a component of euthanasia that has been offered to many caregivers over the years. Providing time alone with the pet is important to some, but not all. The goal is to offer privacy to everyone and let them decide if it’s necessary. Just before the patient is ready for the euthanasia injection/method, technicians may offer privacy by asking, “He/she is ready now for the next medicine to be given to help them to pass. Would you like some private time before we proceed?” This is a gentle way of giving the choice for some alone time and informing them that their pet is ready for euthanasia itself. After the pet has passed, the caregiver may be asked if they want more private time with their now deceased pet before they depart. If time is limited, this author advocates for ensuring the caregiver has privacy after death to help them process the reality of their pet’s passing. Spending time with their deceased pet is important to many people (seeFigure 10.3).

sect2.title: 10.3.4 Deliver Proper Technique
sect2.para: Technicians may assist the veterinarian with euthanasia, or they may be directed to perform the euthanasia themselves. The technician’s role is to monitor the euthanasia method and help ensure the delivery of proper technique. Although it may feel awkward to give suggestions to a veterinarian on how to improve a euthanasia technique, knowledgeable technicians may speak up, especially if it improves the patient and client experience. Details on proper euthanasia technique methods can be found inChapter 12.

sect2.title: 10.3.5 Establish Rapport
sect2.para: During euthanasia, caregivers seek out veterinary teams they trust and with whom they can communicate openly. Rapport is established between the technician and caregiver at the start of the interaction and carried throughout the appointment. A personal connection revolves around honesty, a genuine interest in caring for the patient, and the use of communication skills.

sect2.title: 10.3.6 Use Pre‐euthanasia Sedation or Anesthesia
sect2.para: The benefits of pre‐euthanasia sleep have been well reported, and it is now widely advocated. Technicians may provide it to patients at the start of the appointment or before any need for patient restraint, such as the necessary handling for placement of an indwelling intravenous catheter. Sedation is a lighter state of relaxation compared to anesthesia and expected unconsciousness. Sedation or anesthesia will be further defined inChapter 11.

sect2.title: 10.3.7 Thorough, Complete Consent
sect2.para: One of the most important tasks for technicians is to acquire caregiver consent before facilitating euthanasia (seeFigure 10.4). Caregivers will sign a document (digital or paper) indicating the veterinary team has full and complete authority to end the life of the patient. If the caregiver cannot sign for some reason, the technician may act as the agent of the owner and sign on their behalf. This should be witnessed by another family member or veterinary team member for added legal protection. The consent form is included in the patient’s medical record.

sect2.title: 10.3.8 Helpful and Compassionate Personnel
sect2.para: Patients and caregivers are fortunate to have veterinary teams seeking ways to lovingly care for them. Technicians providing compassionate responses will demonstrate this to everyone on the team.

sect2.title: 10.3.9 Adequate Time
sect2.para: There are many parts of the euthanasia appointment that take time – more time than might be anticipated by a non‐hospice veterinary team. Euthanasia appointments commonly range from 20 to 60 minutes depending on the availability of team members and comfort room space. Home euthanasias are typically longer, even over two hours for some specialty services. Whether short or long, the goal is to help caregivers feel relaxed and able to forget about the rest of the world for a bit, just focusing on their pet while they say goodbye.

sect2.title: 10.3.10 Narrate the Process
sect2.para: Technicians are often responsible for describing the euthanasia procedure to caregivers. They will inform on such things as maintaining patient comfort, the visible signs of death, and how the procedure will be conducted. Grieving caregivers benefit from clear, concise information in manageable amounts that avoid overwhelming them. SeeSection 10.5 for some possible language suggestions.

sect2.title: 10.3.11 Avoid Pain and Anxiety
sect2.para: Of the 14 essential components, this is arguably the most important to caregivers and their pets. Veterinary teams who place considerable effort in avoiding pain and anxiety during the appointment should have confidence in their protocols, knowing the death experience is as gentle as it can be. A good death is void of such negative states and is facilitated for the patient through slow, considerate handling, the use of distractions, pain‐free drug administration, and allowing the patient to relax at their own pace (e.g. not forcing them into a laying position).

sect2.title: 10.3.12 Safe Space to Gather
sect2.para: Safety during euthanasia refers to both physical and emotional comforts. Caregivers should feel they are safe to cry and show emotion, and technicians themselves should feel safe to do the same. Technicians increase caregiver safety by being empathic and communicative and protecting them from physical harm, such as bites or scratches. Patients also deserve calm and safe euthanasia spaces. Technicians monitor the experience for any risks or dangers that may arise.

sect2.title: 10.3.13 Inclusion of Loved Ones
sect2.para: Modern euthanasia appointments tend to welcome any and all human or animal loved ones who wish to be present. Depending on the space, this may be upwards of 10 people or more; however, it is more common for just a few people to be in attendance. The important thing to consider is what is best for the pet patient at the moment, such as companionship and reduced stress. If a full room leads to increased anxiety, the “less is more” approach is preferred. With companion animals, the goal is to allow trusted companions (human and animal) to be there to lend love and support in the final moments of life (seeFigure 10.5).

sect2.title: 10.3.14 Assistance with Body Care (Aftercare)
sect2.para: Caregivers need guidance on how best to handle their deceased pet’s body. Guidance may come in the form of complete veterinary‐led aftercare management or simply through informing caregivers of their local options. InChapter 13, we will explore the difference between Client Aftercare Ordering Models (CAOM) and Veterinary Aftercare Ordering Models (VAOM). Technicians will help caregivers determine what’s important to them and facilitate their requests.

The information that caregivers need to consider may be placed on the practice website and in EOL care handout materials. The more that can be included on the website the better. This helps caregivers readily find answers to their questionsch0022-c10-bib-0010. An online form may also be created for caregivers to fill in details related to the appointment such as location preferences, special touches, and other caregiver expectations.

sect2.para: Payment for euthanasia is often collected before the appointment begins, thus removing the need to do so during such a sensitive time ch0022-c10-bib-0011. If a form of payment has already been obtained for hospice services, the euthanasia fee may be easily added. Technicians will explain the associated charges and determine if the cost of euthanasia is a concern. The cost of services will vary based on time of day, location, how many veterinary staff are necessary, if body transport to the aftercare facility is needed, and if it’s an emergency or planned euthanasia.

sect2.title: 10.4 Technicians in the Role of Euthanasia Provider
sect2.para: Depending on the region and regulatory context, it may be permissible for a technician to perform the euthanasia procedure itself under the direction of a veterinarian, either to administer the euthanasia solution or use other physical methods to achieve patient death. Technicians who are properly trained in the complete medical act of euthanasia are highly valuable to the veterinary team and can reduce suffering in animal patients, especially in times of crisis. Even in regions and situations where this is permitted, the attending veterinarian will still need to decide if the technician is suitable to help the patient. There may be times when the veterinarian feels they themselves should be the one to proceed.

Technicians may learn the same medical skills needed for euthanasia as veterinarians. Skilled technicians can calculate drug doses and assess the patient’s signalment to determine the best euthanasia method. Thats said, it is preferable for technicians to follow standard operating procedures (SOPs) or clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) approved by the veterinarians in charge of patient care. For example, technicians know ahead of the appointment that feline patients in their practice are preferentially euthanized via the intrarenal injection method in their animal hospice service. When preparing for feline euthanasia, they will give the required pre‐euthanasia anesthetics to induce unconsciousness, then administer the proper dose of euthanasia solution into the kidney. When working with canine patients, the SOP may state that an indwelling intravenous catheter should be placed before the administration of the euthanasia solution, and the technician complies. Standard guidelines might require them to auscultate the heart for 30 seconds to verify death, etc. Technicians will be held accountable for tracking drugs used, writing notes in the medical records, and other post‐appointment tasks.

Technicians may be able to perform euthanasia without an attending veterinarian on the premises as long as it is on the orders of a veterinarian. When this occurs, the technician will want clear instructions on how to proceed, what equipment and supplies to have ready, and who to contact if issues arise. At least one veterinarian on the hospice team should be reachable during such a euthanasia to address emergency questions and triage the situation. If the caregiver decides not to proceed with euthanasia, the technician will comply and stop the euthanasia procedure.

There will be instances when a technician disagrees with the veterinarian’s decision to euthanize a patient. There are many factors a veterinarian must consider and not everything will be discussed with the technician. Technicians have the choice to agree with whatever the veterinarian decides or raise questions over the validity to euthanize. When caregivers are present, veterinarians will take the lead on all decision‐making and communications around euthanasia. Technicians may suggest alternative options to the veterinarian in private and are encouraged to do so if they have a realistic, attainable substitution to euthanasia. When in conversation with a caregiver who is expressing concerns about the euthanasia decision, the technician can excuse themselves and seek out the veterinarian. The technician’s role is to support the caregiver and veterinarian without directly influencing the decision to euthanize. This may be hard for some technicians with strong opinions regarding what they feel is right and wrong and can lead to moral stress.

blockquote.para: Have you ever disagreed with a euthanasia decision?
What circumstances might contribute to this feeling?

sect2.title: 10.5 Communicating Effectively Before, During, and After Euthanasia
sect2.para: Talking about euthanasia and death can be a difficult part of veterinary medicine. Veterinarians find it more challenging to discuss euthanasia with caregivers than to perform the procedurech0022-c10-bib-0006. Veterinary technicians are expected to discuss various parts of euthanasia with caregivers, sometimes with veterinarians in the room but often on their own. In animal hospice work, euthanasia conversations are a regular part of the job and can be very rewarding. Knowing what to say and how to say it builds confident technicians and is a key factor in job satisfaction.

When preparing to talk with caregivers about euthanasia, technicians will want to reflect on the goals of the conversation. As mentioned, it can be difficult for veterinary personnel to have such serious life‐changing discussions with caregivers, and it’s expected that it will be scary for the caregiver too. The number one thing caregivers want to learn from the veterinary team is that euthanasia is the right choicech0022-c10-bib-0012. They seek validation in their decision to euthanize their pet, and this therefore should become part of the conversation, either said aloud or as a subtheme supported by other compassionate statements. Euthanasia decision‐making was discussed in Chapter 8. The focus of this section is practical communication tools and language the technician may apply in euthanasia‐related communication (Communication Corner 10.3).

CAETA has developed the seven habits of good death dialogue (seeTable 10.3) to aid veterinary teams during the euthanasia appointment. The habits are designed to be used by all team members before, during, and after euthanasia to support the conversation goals listed above. For technicians, these will hopefully become second nature and easy to maintain during every appointment.

To illustrate these seven habits, we will consider the steps a technician may take to effectively communicate during a sample euthanasia appointment. Linus, a canine patient, is being euthanized at the hospital due to old age and frailty. The caregivers have arrived with Linus and have settled into the euthanasia room. The technician enters to start the appointment.

listitem.para: Give reassurance: everyone agrees that euthanasia is the best option.
Reduce complications: say things that keep the conversation on the right track.
Provide simple answers: minimize unnecessary dialogue that slows caregiver understanding (i.e. say more with less).
Convey compassion and passion: speak from the head and heart, and ensure caregivers know their thoughts and feelings matter.
Find common ground: caregivers and technicians become a team during euthanasia.
Stay relaxed: avoid mental trauma during the appointment.
Triage effectively: read between the lines to understand the bigger picture.

sect2.para:
Table 10.3
The seven habits of good death dialogue. Source: CAETA.

sect2.title: 10.5.1 Establish Rapport
sect2.para: All communication starts with a good introduction. Technicians will introduce themselves to caregivers with a warm, genuine voice and eye contact. Rapport will be further established by greeting Linus and learning everyone’s names. This is a good time for technicians to start gathering information about the feelings surrounding euthanasia, learn of previous euthanasia experiences if not already known, and get a sense of the emotional support that will be required.

listitem.para: Introduce yourself:
Offer 3–5 empathy statements: (appropriate responses to what the caregiver is saying)
Provide comfort in the room:
“Hello, my name is Kathleen, and I’m the technician who will be supporting you today. It’s an honor to have you here with us, to help Linus on this hard day.”
“What is your name?” (learn everyone’s name in the room)
“It sounds like Linus is very special to your family.”
“His decline with old age has been challenging.”
“You’ve been caring for Linus for such a long time.”
“We never want to say goodbye.”
“We love our pets so much. They give us such joy.”
“My heart is with you.”
“This is such a hard day.”
“Please make yourself comfortable.”
“Let’s lay this blanket down for Linus.”
“Would you like some water?”
“Here are some activities and books for the kids if they want.”

sect2.title: 10.5.2 Find Comfort with Silence
sect2.para: The more comfortable a technician is with their skills, the more likely they will be comfortable sitting in silence with caregivers. Silence within a conversation can feel unnatural and lead many to want to fill the space with talking. However, too much talking can feel overwhelming to grieving caregivers who are trying to process a lot of informationch0022-c10-bib-0013. Taking a pause in the conversation offers everyone a chance to reset and think about what they want for Linus. It is about letting the moment breathe a bit. Finding comfort with silence takes practice. A good way to start is for technicians to take deep breaths during the appointment.

sect2.title: 10.5.3 Use the Basics of Good Communication
sect2.para: Essential communication skills are highlighted inChapters 6 and 7. Here are a few examples that can be applied during euthanasia conversations.

listitem.para: Reflective listening: repeating what was just said by the caregiver.
Summary statements: summarizing the last few thoughts that were said.
Warning shots: letting the caregiver know important information is coming, sometimes bad news.
Open‐ended questions: asking questions that lead to descriptive answers beyond a short yes or no. A good question can generate a lot of information for technicians to utilize.
Caregiver says, “We’ve had Linus for 18 years.”
Caregiver says, “The kids want to be present to say goodbye.”
Technician replies with reverence, “18 years.”
Technician replies, “The kids want to be present. That’s important.”
“It sounds like Linus hasn’t been sleeping well at night and is refusing to eat his favorite foods. And now that it’s hard to give his medications, you are worried about more pain.”
“For Linus’s aftercare needs, you’ve shared that you want a private cremation, a collection of fur from his neck area, and a paw print with the nickname ‘Cutie Pie’. Is this correct?”
“The doctor has something important they want to talk about.”
“We have some concerns about how Linus is going to handle the sedative.”
“What we are about to tell you may feel overwhelming.”
“How did Linus come to be in your life?”
“What were some of his favorite foods?”
“What changes have you been seeing that I can share with the doctor?”
“Tell me about Linus’s behavior over the past few days.”

sect2.title: 10.5.4 Offer Praise
sect2.para: Caregivers often feel doubt during euthanasia appointments. Offering kind words of gratitude and praise can lift spirits, thus reducing anxiety. Technicians can remember the importance of this when reflecting on the most loving thing they can do for caregivers: being kind and gentle.

listitem.para: “You have taken such good care of Linus.”
“He has been so blessed to have your love over the years.”
“Thank you for loving him so deeply.”
“You honor him with your tears.”
“Thank you for letting us take our time today.”

sect2.title: 10.5.5 Piece It Out
sect2.para: Too much information at once can overwhelm caregivers. Technicians can break down what’s said into smaller, more manageable amounts so caregivers can better process the details. Consider briefly describing what’s about to be done before each step of the euthanasia procedure rather than all at once from the beginning.

listitem.para: Everyone is gathered, and it’s time to begin: “Let’s talk about how we will be helping Linus. In a moment, we’ll be giving him medicine to help him sleep. Once in deep sleep, a second medicine is given to help him pass. You may love him and be as close as you wish. This is your time together. What questions do you have for us?”

Give Linus his pre‐euthanasia sedative: “As Linus welcomes this first medicine, he may take a few deep breaths as he welcomes sleep. He may even move his legs a little like he’s dreaming. And his eyes will remain open, even during his passing. This is very natural. This medicine helps to take away any discomfort his body’s been feeling.”

Wait for Linus to fall asleep: “While Linus sleeps, we’ll place a little IV catheter. It’s through this the next medicine will be given to help him pass. We’ll let you know when he is ready. He knows you are right there loving and supporting him.”

Prepare for the euthanasia injection: “Linus is ready now for the next medicine to be given to help him to pass. He may take some deep breaths as his body releases energy. We’ll listen to his heart and let you know when all is quiet. Linus knows you are right here with him, and that you’ve shared this wonderful life together. Would you like some private time with him before we proceed?” (Figure 10.6)

sect2.title: 10.5.6 Create Partnership
sect2.para: Building a trusting relationship during the euthanasia experience requires some level of partnership between the veterinary team, the caregiver, and the patient. Conversations with caregivers include words that convey togetherness rather than separation.

listitem.para: “You are in good hands withus.”
“Let’s sit down together and talk for a bit.”
“Our goal is to understand what everyone is feeling about this decision.”
“We’re going to review things together.”
“Together, we will make this a gentle experience.”

sect2.title: 10.5.7 Attend to Emotional Intelligence
sect2.para: People take years, or entire lifetimes, to master emotional intelligence (EI), but with even a little attention given to it, a technician’s ability to support pet patients and families during euthanasia is limitless. There are five main components to EI: self‐awareness, motivation, empathy, social skills, and self‐regulation. Technicians with strong EI will be better prepared to navigate their feelings and the emotions of caregivers, leading to increased resiliency in animal hospice and euthanasia work.

listitem.para: Self‐awareness: (mindful of your feelings, emotions)
Motivation/passion: (appreciating what drives us)
Empathy: (ability to feel what others are feeling)
Social skills: (how we interact with and influence others)
Self‐regulation: (having control over our physical and emotional state)
“Performing this euthanasia will be hard on me. Today is the anniversary of my own dog’s death.”
“I want to help Linus at home because that’s where I want my own pet to be.”
“My client is overwhelmed with this decision. I know what that’s like.”
“My client is angry. I can use my gentle body language and tone of voice to diffuse him.”
“Things are getting challenging, and my body is tense. Time to take some deep breaths.”

sect2.para: Technicians will develop a rhythm in their conversations with caregivers during the euthanasia appointment. Whether in the home or hospital, certain elements will remain constant and reliable. It eases tension to know what to say and when to say it and makes the euthanasia experience rewarding for many technicians. The focus shifts from doubting oneself to helping the patient, which is the objective.

After the euthanasia procedure is complete, caregivers will need continued support as the appointment draws to a close. When in the hospital setting, technicians may offer more privacy to those who need it and guide caregivers outdoors when they are ready. It is kind to provide some parting statements that keep dialogue open and ongoing support available.

listitem.para: “Take all the time you need.”
“Would you like some water or tissues for the ride home?”
“What questions do you have for us at this time?”
“We will reach out in a day or two to check on you.”
“What an honor to care for your family.”
“We are here when you need us.”

sect2.para: Many of these examples are applicable during mobile euthanasia as well. The main difference will be body removal logistics if the veterinary team is taking the body for aftercare on behalf of the caregiver. These details will be described more inChapter 13.

sect2.title: 10.6 Medical Records
sect2.para: What is said before, during, and after euthanasia is best recorded in patient medical records. Veterinary medical records usually include some parts of the euthanasia discussion, but details tend to be lackingch0022-c10-bib-0014. Technicians have the skills to capture important discussion details in medical records for future review by the whole team. Such details include caregivers’ psychosocial factors around euthanasia (e.g. previous experiences, concerns) and anything they share related to preplanning expectations. The technician will record the veterinarian’s perspective on such things as timing for euthanasia, options beyond euthanasia (palliative care), and details related to the procedure after it’s complete. The goal is to increase the amount of information entered into medical records to improve patient care and standardization of protocols (Table 10.4).

sect2.title: 10.7 Takeaways

listitem.para: Euthanasia has evolved well past the simple injection or method. It is considered to be an experience where loved ones can gather to say goodbye.
Technicians will help with every aspect of the euthanasia appointment, including performing the procedure when allowed and necessary.
Technicians can help caregivers feel more at ease by assisting with appointment preplanning and using strong communication skills.
The 14 Essential Components of Good Euthanasia may be used as a template for every appointment.
Technicians may help veterinarians develop detailed euthanasia medical records.
